_metadata.context: Integrated Framework for Inquiry and Creation

concepts.name: Adaptation
concepts.theory_application: Adjust to new conditions or information.

variations.theory: Definition: Adaptation is the conscious decision to switch methods. Procedural Link: The action is to make the conscious decision to switch experimental methods or analytical approaches in response to unexpected data or resource changes.

Definition: Adaptation is the ability to adjust process. Procedural Link: The action is to ensure the core principle of Agile; the ability to adjust priorities, scope, or process in response to new information (Inspect and Adapt).
Definition: Adaptation is modifying the writing process. Procedural Link: The action is to modify the writing process, schedule, or research method based on a review of the work's process log.
Definition: Adaptation is changing the studio workflow. Procedural Link: The action is to change the studio workflow, material, or approach in response to a process critique.

Definition: Adaptation is adjusting governance. Procedural Link: The action is to ensure the capacity of the organization or community to adjust its governance in response to emergent social or environmental needs.

concepts.name: Awareness
concepts.theory_application: Cultivate conscious attention to internal and external states.

variations.theory: Definition: Awareness is attention to process and bias. Procedural Link: The action is to cultivate the metacognitive state of being consciously attentive to one's research process, cognitive biases, and time allocation.

Definition: Awareness is collective awareness of process health. Procedural Link: The action is to cultivate the collective awareness of the team's process health, including flow efficiency, work-in-progress limits, and morale.
Definition: Awareness is self-awareness of habits. Procedural Link: The action is to cultivate the writer’s self-awareness of their own writing habits, procrastination triggers, and argument flaws.

Definition: Awareness is understanding creative flow. Procedural Link: The action is to cultivate the artist’s metacognitive understanding of their creative flow, personal aesthetic rules, and recurring creative blocks.

Definition: Awareness is communal self-awareness. Procedural Link: The action is to cultivate communal self-awareness of the group's current emotional state, power dynamics, and adherence to principles.

concepts.name: Contemplation
concepts.theory_application: Engage in deep, sustained thought or reflection.

variations.theory: Definition: Contemplation is quiet reflection. Procedural Link: The action is to schedule deliberate, quiet time to reflect on complex data or paradoxes to allow deeper insights to emerge.

Definition: Contemplation is strategic reflection. Procedural Link: The action is to set aside time for strategic reflection outside of the immediate pressures of feature delivery (Consolidation Period - N97).
Definition: Contemplation is sustained, quiet thought. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in sustained, quiet thought about a dense passage or theoretical problem.
Definition: Contemplation is meditative practice. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the meditative practice of giving undivided attention to the creative process or the finished work.
Definition: Contemplation is self-inquiry. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the practice of Self-Inquiry (N81), turning attention inward to diagnose one's motivations and attachments.

concepts.name: Double-Loop Learning
concepts.theory_application: Question underlying assumptions and goals, rather than just adjusting actions.

variations.theory: Definition: Double-loop learning is questioning the underlying assumption. Procedural Link: The goal is to go beyond fixing a flawed experimental outcome (single-loop) to questioning the underlying scientific assumption or flawed theory (double-loop).

Definition: Double-loop learning is questioning the underlying process. Procedural Link: The goal is to go beyond fixing a bug (single-loop) to questioning the underlying process or flawed assumption that caused it. (Ref: Argyris, 1991)

Definition: Double-loop learning is questioning the underlying framework. Procedural Link: The goal is to go beyond fixing a logical error to questioning the underlying theoretical framework that created the error.

Definition: Double-loop learning is questioning the fundamental philosophy. Procedural Link: The goal is to go beyond fixing a failed design to questioning the fundamental design philosophy that led to the attempt.
Definition: Double-loop learning is questioning core beliefs. Procedural Link: The action is to question the core communal beliefs or values that led to a negative systemic outcome.

concepts.name: Inventory
concepts.theory_application: Systematically count and assess available resources or assets.

variations.theory: Definition: Inventory is taking stock of the project's status. Procedural Link: The action is to take stock of the project's current status: what data is collected, what code is deployed, and what problems remain.

Definition: Inventory is reviewing backlog and counting resources. Procedural Link: The action is to review the current state of the backlog, identifying bottlenecks, and counting the resources consumed (e.g., measuring Cycle Time - N105).

Definition: Inventory is reviewing written prose and research needed. Procedural Link: The action is to review the amount of written prose, collected fieldwork, and remaining research needed for completion.
Definition: Inventory is cataloging assets. Procedural Link: The action is to catalog all sketches, models, materials, and digital assets.
Definition: Inventory is a formal check-in on commitments. Procedural Link: The action is to conduct a formal check-in on the status of all ethical commitments and community relationships.

concepts.name: Metacognition
concepts.theory_application: Think about thinking; monitor and regulate one's own cognitive processes.

variations.theory: Definition: Metacognition is conscious reflection on the process. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the conscious reflection on the process of scientific thinking and problem-solving to improve efficiency and reduce bias.

Definition: Metacognition is diagnosing the workflow. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the practice of thinking about thinking: diagnosing the workflow itself (e.g., why is this slow? where are we stuck?).

Definition: Metacognition is self-reflection on the drafting process. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the writer’s self-reflection on their drafting process, focusing on habits and cognitive blocks.
Definition: Metacognition is articulating tacit rules. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the artist’s ability to articulate the tacit rules that guide their creative, intuitive process.

Definition: Metacognition is the highest state of self-awareness. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the highest state of self-awareness and control over one's own cognitive and moral conduct.

concepts.name: Observation
concepts.theory_application: Watch and record behavior or performance without interfering.

variations.theory: Definition: Observation is monitoring system performance. Procedural Link: The action is to monitor system performance metrics, error rates, and the behavior of the research team.

Definition: Observation is monitoring communication patterns. Procedural Link: The action is to monitor the Kanban board (N103), Burndown charts, and team communication patterns for signs of friction.

Definition: Observation is observing group engagement. Procedural Link: The action is to ensure the writer or group leader observes the group’s engagement and emotional state during a writing session.
Definition: Observation is viewing work as an outsider. Procedural Link: The action is to ensure the artist views their work as an outsider, detaching from their own expectation to see true flaws.
Definition: Observation is intentional witnessing. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the intentional, non-judgmental witnessing of a social ritual or interaction.

concepts.name: Oversight
concepts.theory_application: Supervise and manage a system or process to ensure it meets its goals.

variations.theory: Definition: Oversight is strategic management of the system. Procedural Link: The action is to fulfill the strategic, leadership function of managing the entire inquiry system across multiple cycles and teams.

Definition: Oversight is managing the product portfolio. Procedural Link: The action is to fulfill the executive function of managing the whole product portfolio, allocating resources, and selecting which initiatives to fund next (Portfolio Review - N99).

Definition: Oversight is steering the intellectual trajectory. Procedural Link: The action is to fulfill the role of head of a department or research center steering the intellectual trajectory and managing the collective academic work.
Definition: Oversight is managing creative output. Procedural Link: The action is to fulfill the leadership role of an artistic director managing the creative output of a studio or company.
Definition: Oversight is ultimate leadership responsibility. Procedural Link: The action is to fulfill the ultimate leadership responsibility for the health and sustainability of the community.
Complex Adaptive Systems (CAS). Procedural Link: Treat the team as a semi-autonomous system; manage boundaries, not individuals.

concepts.name: Process Improvement
concepts.theory_application: Identify and implement changes to a process to improve its efficiency or effectiveness.

variations.theory: Definition: Process improvement is preventing recurring errors. Procedural Link: The action is to implement changes to protocols, lab structures, or data handling techniques to prevent recurring errors.

Definition: Process improvement is reducing waste. Procedural Link: The action is to implement systemic changes (e.g., implementing WIP limits - N104, defining new APIs) to reduce waste and bottlenecks.

Definition: Process improvement is developing new protocols. Procedural Link: The action is to develop new writing protocols or collaborative research methods based on lessons learned from past projects.
Definition: Process improvement is developing new heuristics. Procedural Link: The action is to develop new studio routines or heuristics (N77) to overcome chronic creative blocks.

Definition: Process improvement is changing governance structure. Procedural Link: The action is to implement a systemic, long-term change to the governance or communication structure to improve collaboration.

concepts.name: Reflection
concepts.theory_application: Look back on a period of time or an event to evaluate what happened and why.

variations.theory: Definition: Reflection is formally reviewing the past cycle. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the activity of formally reviewing the past cycle to extract non-obvious lessons (e.g., Lab Meeting - N70).
Definition: Reflection is inspecting process health. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the formal team ceremony of the Sprint Retrospective (N44) for inspecting process health.

Definition: Reflection is systematically questioning past events. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the core of reflective practice (N74); systematically questioning past events to transform tacit experience into explicit knowledge.
Definition: Reflection is analyzing the artistic workflow. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the Process Critique (N76) where the artistic workflow is analyzed as a system to be improved.
Definition: Reflection is the deliberate pause. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the deliberate pause to review recent communal actions against core values.

concepts.name: Reflective Practice
concepts.theory_application: Engage in a continuous cycle of action and reflection to improve performance and understanding.

variations.theory: Definition: Reflective practice is translating experience into expertise. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the discipline of consistently reviewing one's own actions and processes to translate individual experience into professional expertise. (N74)

Definition: Reflective practice is analyzing contributions to performance. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the professional habit of continuously analyzing one's own contributions to team performance and process friction.

Definition: Reflective practice is systematic self-analysis. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the systematic self-analysis by the scholar to understand how their background and biases influence their research design.

Definition: Reflective practice is maintaining a process journal. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the artist's disciplined maintenance of a Process Journal (N31) to record insights and process changes.

Definition: Reflective practice is integrating experience and integrated knowledge. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the lifelong discipline of integrating experience and integrated knowledge into ethical action.

concepts.name: Retrospective
concepts.theory_application: Look back on a completed phase of work to identify lessons learned and improve future performance.

variations.theory: Definition: Retrospective is analyzing the process of the experiment. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in a formal, time-boxed meeting to collectively analyze the past work cycle's process, identifying flaws in the protocol or teamwork that should be fixed for the next cycle. (N44)
Definition: Retrospective is inspecting process health. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the formal team ceremony of the Sprint Retrospective (N44) for inspecting process health.

Definition: Retrospective is distilling key learnings. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in a structured meeting for a Writing Group (N73) to discuss progress, troubleshoot process blocks, and commit to next steps. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in a structured meeting for a Writing Group (N73) to discuss progress, troubleshoot process blocks, and commit to next steps.

Definition: Retrospective is analyzing the artistic workflow. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in a Studio Critique (N76) focused on the efficiency, coherence, and principles of the creative process.

Definition: Retrospective is facilitated dialogue. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in a facilitated Council (N65) or dialogue session to reflect on collective actions and reaffirm shared agreements.

concepts.name: Self-Regulation
concepts.scenario: A research team facing burnout during a long trial.
concepts.theory_application: Monitor and control one's own behavior, emotions, and thoughts to achieve a goal.

variations.theory: Definition: Self-regulation is managing attention and bias. Procedural Link: The action is to aim for the capacity of the scientist to manage their own attention, biases, and emotional responses to data to maintain objectivity.
variations.rubric: Aims to maintain objectivity via regulation.

variations.theory: Definition: Self-regulation is diagnosing and fixing process. Procedural Link: The action is to aim for the capacity of the team to diagnose and fix its own process without external help (the self-managing team).

Definition: Self-regulation is managing motivation and argument development. Procedural Link: The action is to aim for the scholar’s ability to manage procrastination, motivation, and argument development autonomously.

Definition: Self-regulation is command over tools and focus. Procedural Link: The action is to aim for the artist's complete command over their tools, habits, and focus to achieve flow state and sustained creativity.
variations.rubric: Aims for flow state and sustained creativity.

variations.theory: Definition: Self-regulation is governing oneself. Procedural Link: The action is to aim for the capacity of the individual and community to govern themselves according to integrated values and integrated knowledge.
variations.rubric: Aims to govern themselves via values.

concepts.name: Tuckman's Stages

variations.theory: Teams must go through conflict (Storming) to reach performance. Procedural Link: Diagnose the current stage and apply 'Directive' or 'Supportive' leadership accordingly.

concepts.scenario: A new team is fighting constantly.
concepts.theory_application: Diagnose team maturity (Forming, Storming, Norming, Performing) to select the right leadership style.

concepts.name: Kotter / ADKAR

variations.theory: Change happens at the individual level (Awareness, Desire, Knowledge, Ability, Reinforcement). Procedural Link: Assess the team's ADKAR status and intervene where they are stuck.

concepts.theory_application: Manage the human side of organizational change using a structured model.

concepts.name: Operations Research

variations.theory: Optimization. Procedural Link: Use mathematical modeling to maximize efficiency under constraints.

concepts.theory_application: Use advanced analytical methods to help make better decisions.

concepts.name: Value Chain Analysis

variations.theory: Value Chain. Link: Map Primary vs. Support activities to find margin.
Flow Analysis. Link: Identify where the 'stock' of knowledge gets stuck in the 'pipes' of process.

concepts.scenario: A team feeling busy but producing little value.
concepts.theory_application: Analyze the workflow to identify where value is created and where it is lost (friction), then optimize the chain.
